API¶

main.py¶

General functions for creating graphics.

algoraphics.main.add_margin(bounds, margin)¶

Add margin to bounds.

A convenience function used when generating objects to avoid issues at the edges of the region or canvas.

Parameters:
  • bounds (tuple) – A tuple of min x, max x, min y, and max y.
  • margin (float|int) – The width of the margin.
Returns:

Bounds that include the margin on all sides.
Return type:

tuple
algoraphics.main.arith_seq(start, stop, length)¶

Generate an arithmetic sequence.

Parameters:
  • start (float) – The first value in the sequence.
  • stop (float) – The last value in the sequence.
  • length (int) – The length of the the sequence.
Returns:

The generated sequence.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.main.background(fill, w, h, margin=0)¶

Create a background color for the canvas.

See region_background to set background for a specific region.

Parameters:
  • fill (color) – The background color.
  • w (int) – width of canvas.
  • h (int) – height of canvas.
  • margin (int) – width of margin to include to avoid edge artifacts.
Returns:

A filled rectangular polygon covering the canvas.
Return type:

tuple
algoraphics.main.bounding_box(shapes)¶

Find bounding box of shape or shape collection.

Parameters:shapes (dict|list) – One or more shapes.
Returns:The min x, max x, min y, and max y coordinates of the input.
Return type:tuple
algoraphics.main.centroid(shape)¶

Find the centroid of a shape.

Parameters:shape (dict) – A shape.
Returns:A point.
Return type:tuple
algoraphics.main.coverage(obj)¶

Create shapely object.

Used to calculate area/coverage.

algoraphics.main.flatten(objects)¶

Create a flattened list from a nested list.

Parameters:objects (object) – A nested list or a non-list.
Returns:The non-list elements within the input.
Return type:list
algoraphics.main.geom_seq(start, stop, length)¶

Generate geometric sequence.

Parameters:
  • start (float) – The first value in the sequence.
  • stop (float) – The last value in the sequence.
  • length (int) – Length of the sequence.
Returns:

The generated sequence.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.main.keep_points_inside(points, boundary)¶

Keep points that lie within a boundary.

Parameters:
  • points (list) – A list of points.
  • boundary (dict|list) – One or more shapes giving the boundary.
algoraphics.main.keep_shapes_inside(shapes, boundary)¶

Remove shapes from (nested) list if they lie entirely outside the boundary.

Used to optimize SVG file without altering appearance.

Parameters:
  • shapes (list) – A list of shapes.
  • boundary (dict|list) – One or more shapes giving the boundary.
algoraphics.main.path_points(path)¶

Get skeleton points of path.

Useful for finding an approximate bounding box for a path.

algoraphics.main.polygon_area(vertices)¶

Find the area of a polygon.

Parameters:vertices (list) – The vertex points.
Returns:The area.
Return type:float
algoraphics.main.polygon_centroid(vertices)¶

Find the centroid of a polygon.

Parameters:vertices (list) – A list of vertex points.
Returns:A point.
Return type:tuple
algoraphics.main.random_walk(min_val, max_val, max_step, n, start=None)¶

Generate a random walk sequence.

Steps are sampled from a uniform random distribution.

Parameters:
  • min_val (float) – Values will not fall below this value.
  • max_val (float) – Values will not fall above this value.
  • max_step (flot) – Maximum magnitude of each step.
  • n (int) – Length of the sequence.
  • start (number) – The starting value.
Returns:

The generated sequence.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.main.region_background(region, color)¶

Add background color to clipped region.

Adds a filled rectangle to the beginning of the region’s members.

Parameters:
  • region (dict) – A clipped group object.
  • color (color|function) – A color or function to apply to the region.
algoraphics.main.remove_hidden(shapes)¶

Remove shapes from (nested) list if they are entirely covered.

Used to optimize SVG file without altering appearance, e.g. when randomly placing objects to fill a region. Ignores opacity when determining overlap.

Parameters:shapes (list) – A list of shapes.
algoraphics.main.reorder_objects(objects, by='random', w=None, h=None)¶

Reorder objects in list.

Used to change order in which objects are drawn.

Parameters:
  • objects (list) – A list whose items are shapes or lists.
  • by (str) – ‘random’ to shuffle objects. ‘out to in’ to arrange objects closer to the center on top of (later in list) those further from the center. Distance is determined by furthest corner of bounding box so that smaller objects tend to be arranged on top of larger ones that surround them.
  • w (float|int) – Canvas width, used to get center when by=’out to in’.
  • h (float|int) – Canvas height, used to get center when by=’out to in’.
algoraphics.main.reposition(shapes, position, h_align='left', v_align='bottom')¶

Align one or more shapes to a reference point.

Parameters:
  • shapes (dict|list) – One or more shapes.
  • poisition (tuple) – reference point.
  • h_align (str) – ‘left’ to move left bound to reference point. ‘center’ to horizontally center object around reference point. ‘right’ to move right bound to reference point.
  • v_align (str) – ‘bottom’ to move lower bound to reference point. ‘middle’ to vertically center object around reference point. ‘top’ to move upper bound to reference point.
algoraphics.main.rotate_shapes(shapes, angle, pivot=(0, 0))¶

Rotate one or more shapes around a point.

Parameters:
  • shapes (dict|list) – One or more shapes.
  • angle (float|int) – The angle of rotation in degrees.
  • pivot (tuple) – The rotation pivot point.
algoraphics.main.rotated_bounding_box(shapes, angle)¶

Find the rotated bounding box of a shape or shape collection.

Parameters:
  • shapes (dict|list) – One or more shapes.
  • angle (float|int) – The orientation of the bounding box in degrees.
Returns:

The min x, max x, min y, and max y coordinates in rotated space. Anything created using these coordinates must then be rotated by the same angle around the origin to be in the right place.
Return type:

tuple
algoraphics.main.sample_points_in_shape(shape, n)¶

Sample random points inside a shape.

Parameters:
  • shape (dict) – A shape (currently works for polygons and splines).
  • n (int) – Number of points to sample.
Returns:

The sampled points.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.main.scale_path(path, cx, cy=None)¶

Resize path by a factor (radii currently scale by cx).

algoraphics.main.set_style(obj, attribute, value)¶

Set style attribute of one or more shapes.

Parameters:
  • obj (dict|list) – A shape or (nested) list of shapes.
  • attribute (str) – Name of the style attribute (replace ‘-‘ with ‘_’).
  • value (str|number|function) – either a single value or a function that returns values when called with no arguments.
algoraphics.main.shuffled(items)¶

Create shuffled version of a list.

Parameters:items (list) – A list of items.
Returns:A new list with same objects as input but reordered.
Return type:list
algoraphics.main.translate_shapes(shapes, dx, dy)¶

Shift the location of one or more shapes.

Parameters:
  • shapes (list|dict) – One or more shapes.
  • dx (float|int) – Horizontal shift.
  • dy (float|int) – Vertical shift.

color.py¶

Functions for working with colors.

class algoraphics.color.Color(hsl=None, hue=None, sat=None, li=None, rgb=None, RGB=None)¶

Object to represent a color or distribution of colors.

algoraphics.color.average_color(colors)¶

Find average of list of colors.

Currently, this finds the arithmetic mean in RGB color space.

Parameters:colors (list) – A list of Color objects.
Returns:The average color.
Return type:Color
algoraphics.color.color_mixture(color1, color2, proportion=0.5, mode='rgb')¶

Get mixture of two colors at specified proportion.

Parameters:
  • color1 (tuple) – An RGB or HSL tuple.
  • color2 (tuple) – An RGB or HSL tuple, must match type of color1.
  • proportion (float) – Fraction of mixture coming from color2.
  • mode (str) – Either ‘rgb’ or ‘hsl’.
Returns:

An RGB or HSL tuple.
Return type:

tuple
algoraphics.color.contrasting_lightness(color, light_diff)¶

Get color with contrasting lightness to reference color.

Color is lighter if original lightness is < 0.5 and darker otherwise. Used to create color pairs for a mixture of light and dark colors.

Parameters:
  • color (tuple) – An RGB tuple.
  • light_diff (float) – Magnitude of difference in lightness, between 0 and 1.
Returns:

An RGB tuple.
Return type:

tuple
algoraphics.color.hsv_array_to_rgb(hsv)¶

Convert matrix of HSV values to rgb.

algoraphics.color.map_colors_to_array(values, colors, period, gradient_mode='rgb')¶

Map 2D array of values to a cyclical color gradient.

If values vary continuously in space, this produces a cyclical color gradient.

Parameters:
  • values (numpy.ndarray) – A 2D array. Values should range from 0, inclusive, to len(colors) + 1, exclusive. Each value corresponds to a proportional mixture of the colors at the two indices it is between (with values higher than the last index cycling back to the first color).
  • colors (list) – A list of Color objects.
  • gradient_mode (str) – Either ‘rgb’ or ‘hsv’ to indicate how the colors are interpolated.
Returns:

A 3D array of RGB values (RGB mode because this is used for PIL images).
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
algoraphics.color.rand_col_nearby(color, hue_tol, sat_tol, light_tol)¶

Select random color within range of reference color.

Parameters:
  • color (tuple) – An RGB tuple.
  • hue_tol (float) – Maximum hue deviation, usually 0 to 0.5.
  • sat_tol (float) – Maximum saturation deviation, usually 0 to 1.
  • light_tol (float) – Maximum lightness deviation, usually 0 to 1.
Returns:

An RGB tuple.
Return type:

tuple
algoraphics.color.rgb_array_to_hsv(rgb)¶

Convert matrix of rgb values to HSV.

filaments.py¶

Create meandering segmented filaments.

algoraphics.filaments.filament(start, direction, width, seg_length, n_segments)¶

Generate a meandering segmented filament.

Parameters:
  • start (point) – The midpoint of first edge of the filament.
  • direction (Param) – The direction (in degrees) of each segment. Recommended to be a Param with a delta Param for a meandering filament. Nested delta Params will produce meandering from higher-order random walks.
  • width (float|int) – The width of the filament (at segment joining edges).
  • seg_length (float|int) – Average side length of each segment.
  • n_segments (int) – Number of segments in the filament.
Returns:

A list of polygons (the segments in order).
Return type:

list

geom.py¶

General functions involving points in 2D space.

class algoraphics.geom.Rtree(points=None)¶

TODO

algoraphics.geom.angle_between(p1, p2, p3)¶

Return the angle (in radians) between segment p2->p1 and p2->p3.

The angle can be negative.

algoraphics.geom.deg(rad)¶

Convert radians to degrees.

algoraphics.geom.distance(p1, p2)¶

Return the distance between two points.

algoraphics.geom.endpoint(start, angle, distance)¶

Return a point some distance from a starting point in the direction (in radians) of angle.

algoraphics.geom.get_nearest(points, point, index=False)¶

Find the nearest point in a list to a target point.

Parameters:
  • points (list) – A list of points.
  • point (point) – The target point.
  • index (bool) – Whether to return the point or its index in the list.
Returns:

If index is False, returns point, otherwise returns index of point in list.
Return type:

tuple|int
algoraphics.geom.horizontal_range(points)¶

Return the magnitude of the horizontal range of a list of points.

algoraphics.geom.in_box(point, x_min, x_max, y_min, y_max)¶

Determine if a point lies within the specified bounds.

algoraphics.geom.in_ellipse(point, x_min, x_max, y_min, y_max)¶

Determine if a point lies within an ellipse with the specified bounds.

algoraphics.geom.interpolate(points, spacing)¶

Insert interpolated points.

Insert equally-spaced, linearly interpolated points into list such that consecutive points are no more than ‘spacing’ distance apart.

Parameters:
  • points (list) – A list of points.
  • spacing (float|int) – Maximum distance between adjacent points.
algoraphics.geom.is_clockwise(points)¶

Determine if a set of polygon points goes in clockwise or counterclockwise direction.

If edges cross, it gives the more prominent direction.

algoraphics.geom.jitter_points(points, deviation, type)¶

Add noise to the locations of points.

Parameters:
  • points (list) – A list of points.
  • deviation (float|int) – For gaussian jitter, the standard deviation. For uniform jitter, the maximum distance.
  • type (str) – The type of noise, ‘gaussian’ or ‘uniform’.
algoraphics.geom.jittered_points(points, deviation, type)¶

Like jitter_points but returns jittered points, not affecting the original list.

algoraphics.geom.line_to_polygon(points, width)¶

Convert a sequence of points to a path outline.

Imagining the points were connected with a stroke with positive width, the outline of the stroke is returned.

Parameters:
  • points (list) – A list of line points.
  • width (float) – Width of the path to be outlined.
Returns:

A list of points.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.geom.midpoint(p1, p2)¶

Return the midpoint between two points.

algoraphics.geom.move_toward(start, target, distance)¶

Return a point some distance from a starting point in the direction of a target point.

algoraphics.geom.points_on_arc(center, radius, theta_start, theta_end, spacing)¶

Generate points along an arc.

Parameters:
  • center (point) – The center of the arc.
  • radius (float|int) – The radius of the arc.
  • theta_start (float|int) – The starting position in degrees.
  • theta_end (float|int) – The ending position in degrees.
  • spacing (float|int) – The approximate distance between adjacent points.
Returns:

A list of points.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.geom.points_on_line(start, end, spacing)¶

Generate points along a line.

Parameters:
  • start (point) – The first point.
  • end (point) – The last point.
  • spacing (float|int) – The approximate (max) distance between adjacent points.
Returns:

A list of points.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.geom.rad(deg)¶

Convert degrees to radians.

algoraphics.geom.rand_point_on_circle(c, r)¶

Return random point on circle with center c and radius r.

algoraphics.geom.rotate_and_move(start, ref, angle, distance)¶

Get a point some distance from a starting point in a direction relative to another point.

Combines rotated_point and move_toward.

algoraphics.geom.rotated_point(point, pivot, angle)¶

Return the point resulting from rotating point around pivot point by angle (in radians).

algoraphics.geom.scale_points(points, cx, cy=None)¶

Scale the coordinates of points.

Parameters:
  • points (list) – A list of points, which can be nested.
  • cx (float|int) – The horizontal scale factor.
  • cy (float|int) – The vertical scale factor. If omitted, y-coordinates will be scaled by cx.
algoraphics.geom.scaled_point(point, cx, cy=None)¶

Return the new location of point after scaling coordinates.

Provide either one scaling factor or cx and cy.

algoraphics.geom.translate_points(points, dx, dy)¶

Shift the location of points.

Parameters:
  • points (list) – A list of points, which can be nested.
  • dx (float) – movement in x direction.
  • dy (float) – movement in y direction.
algoraphics.geom.translated_point(point, dx, dy)¶

Return the point resulting from translating point by dx and dy.

grid.py¶

Functions involving grids, whether the cells are pixels or otherwise.

algoraphics.grid.grid_tree(rows, cols)¶

Generate random spanning tree for a grid.

Tree connects adjacent elements of a grid. Used for pixels and for other grids.

Parameters:
  • rows (int) – Number of rows in grid.
  • cols (int) – Number of cols in grid.
Returns:

A 2D binary array with dimensions in sparse format indicating which cells are connected.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
algoraphics.grid.grid_tree_dists(rows, cols)¶

Generate array of random spanning tree distances.

Each value is the distance to (0, 0) along a spanning tree. Map a cyclical color gradient to create a billowing effect.

Parameters:
  • rows (int) – Number of rows in grid.
  • cols (int) – Number of cols in grid.
Returns:

A 2D array of integers.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
algoraphics.grid.grid_tree_edges(rows, cols)¶

Generate edges of random spanning tree for a grid.

Parameters:
  • rows (int) – Number of rows in grid.
  • cols (int) – Number of cols in grid.
Returns:

A list of ((r1, c1), (r2, c2)) coordinate tuple pairs.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.grid.grid_tree_neighbors(rows, cols)¶

Generate random spanning tree for a grid and return neighbor array.

Parameters:
  • rows (int) – Number of rows in grid.
  • cols (int) – Number of cols in grid.
Returns:

A 3D boolean array (rows x cols x [d?, r?, u?, l?]).
Return type:

numpy.ndarray

images.py¶

Generate graphics based on images.

algoraphics.images.array_to_image(array, scale=True)¶

Create an image from a 2D or 3D array.

Parameters:
  • array (numpy.ndarray) – A numpy array: 2D for grayscale or 3D for RGB.
  • scale (bool) – If True, values in 2D array will be scaled so that the highest values are 255 (white).
Returns:

A PIL image in RGB mode.
Return type:

Image
algoraphics.images.color_distances(pixels, color)¶

Get color distance from reference color for every pixel.

Parameters:
  • pixels (numpy.ndarray) – A 3D array corresponding to RGB pixels.
  • color (Color) – A reference color.
Returns:

A 2D array of distances between 0 and 1.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
algoraphics.images.encode_image(image, frmt)¶

Encode an image as a data string.

Used to embed images in SVG.

Parameters:
  • image (Image) – A PIL image.
  • frmt (str) – Either ‘JPEG’ or ‘PNG’.
Returns:

The image encoding.
Return type:

str
algoraphics.images.fill_shapes_from_image(shapes, image)¶

Fill shapes according to their corresponding image region.

Faster than region_color which samples points, but should only be used for regular shapes like tiles since it colors according to the centroid, which may not be inside the shape if it is irregular.

Parameters:
  • shapes (list) – A list of shapes.
  • image (Image) – A PIL image.
algoraphics.images.get_color_regions(image, color, smoothness=5, in_param=0.05, out_param=0.3)¶

Get shapes corresponding to image regions matching a color.

algoraphics.images.image_regions(image, n_segments=100, compactness=10, smoothness=0, simplify=1, expand=2, curvature=0.2)¶

Get spline shapes corresponding to image regions.

Parameters:
  • image (Image) – A PIL image.
  • n_segments (int) – Approximate number of desired segments.
  • compactness (float) – A higher value produces more compact, square-like segments. Try values along log-scale, e.g. 0.1, 1, 10, 100.
  • smoothness (float) – The width of gaussian smoothing applied before segmentation.
  • simplify (float) – Maximum distance from the edge of a simplified shape to its actual boundary when reducing the number of points, or None for no simplification.
  • expand (int) – Number of pixels to expand each segment in every direction to avoid gaps between adjacent shapes.
  • curvature (float) – The degree of curvature in spline. Usually between zero and one.
Returns:

A list of spline shapes, generally in order from left to right and then bottom to top.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.images.open_image(path)¶

Load a PIL image from file.

algoraphics.images.pad_array(pixels, margin=1)¶

Create a new pixel array with added padding.

Adds additional rows and columns of zeros to four edges of matrix. Used to enable finding a contour around a segment at the edge of an image and to allow segments to be expanded to overlap each other.

Parameters:
  • pixels (numpy.ndarray) – A 2D array of pixels.
  • margin (int) – The width of padding on each side.
Returns:

A 2D array with 2 * margin added to both dimensions.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
algoraphics.images.region_color(outline, image, n_points=10)¶

Find representative color for an image region.

Parameters:
  • outline (shape) – A shape corresponding to an image region to sample.
  • image (Image) – A PIL image.
  • n_points (int) – Number of points to sample.
Returns:

The average color of the sampled image points.
Return type:

Color
algoraphics.images.resize_image(image, width, height)¶

Downscale an image.

Scales according to whichever of width or height is not None. Only scales down.

Parameters:
  • image (Image) – A PIL image.
  • width (int) – The new width. If None, scales according to height.
  • height (int) – The new height. If None, scales according to width.
algoraphics.images.sample_colors(image, points)¶

Sample colors from an image.

Parameters:
  • image (Image) – A PIL image.
  • points (list|tuple) – A list of image coordinates, or a single coordinate.
Returns:

A list of Color objects corresponding to points, or a single color if input is a single point.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.images.segment_image(image, n_segments=100, compactness=10, smoothness=0)¶

Divide image into segments.

Used by image_regions().

Parameters:
  • image (Image) – A PIL image.
  • n_segments (int) – Approximate number of desired segments.
  • compactness (float) – A higher value produces more compact, square-like segments. Try values along log-scale, e.g. 0.1, 1, 10, 100.
  • smoothness (float) – The width of gaussian smoothing applied before segmentation.
Returns:

A 2D array of integer segment labels.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
algoraphics.images.segments_to_shapes(seg, simplify=None, expand=1, curvature=0.2)¶

Convert an array of segment labels to spline shapes.

Used by image_regions().

Parameters:
  • seg (numpy.ndarray) – A 2D array of segment labels.
  • simplify (float) – Maximum distance from the edge of a simplified shape to the actual boundary when reducing number of points, or None for no simplification.
  • expand (int) – Number of pixels to expand each segment in every direction to avoid gaps between adjacent shapes.
  • curvature (float) – The degree of curvature for the splines. Usually between zero and one.
Returns:

A list of spline shapes, generally in order from left to right and then bottom to top.
Return type:

list

mazes.py¶

Create maze-like fill patterns.

class algoraphics.mazes.Maze_Style¶

TODO

class algoraphics.mazes.Maze_Style_Jagged(min_w, max_w)¶

Generate pieces for jagged maze.

Parameters:
  • min_w (float) – Minimum width of channel segment relative to cell width.
  • max_w (float) – Maximum width of channel segment relative to cell width.
class algoraphics.mazes.Maze_Style_Pipes(rel_thickness)¶

Generate pieces for curved pipes.

Parameters:rel_thickness (float) – Channel width relative to cell width, from 0 to 1.
class algoraphics.mazes.Maze_Style_Round(rel_thickness)¶

Generate pieces for very curvy pipes.

Parameters:rel_thickness (float) – Channel width relative to cell width, from 0 to 1.
class algoraphics.mazes.Maze_Style_Straight(rel_thickness)¶

Generate pieces for simple right-angle maze.

Parameters:rel_thickness (float) – Channel width relative to cell width, from 0 to 1.
algoraphics.mazes.fill_maze(outline, spacing, style, rotation=None)¶

Fill a region with a maze-like pattern.

Parameters:
  • outline (dict|list) – The shape/s that will become the clip.
  • spacing (float|int) – The cell width of the grid.
  • style (Maze_Style) – An object specifying how the maze path is to be drawn.
  • rotation (float|int) – The orientation of the grid in degrees.
Returns:

A group with clip.
Return type:

dict
algoraphics.mazes.fill_maze_hue_rotate(outline, spacing, style, color)¶

Fill a region with mazes with hue-dependent orientation.

Used for texturing image regions so that adjacent regions of similar color blend together while contrasting with regions of different color.

Parameters:
  • outline (dict|list) – The shape/s that will become the clip.
  • spacing (float|int) – The cell width of the grid.
  • style (Maze_Style) – An object specifying how the maze path is to be drawn.
  • color (color) – The fill color for the maze.
Returns:

A group with clip.
Return type:

dict
algoraphics.mazes.maze(rows, cols, spacing, start, style)¶

Generate a maze-like pattern spanning the specified grid.

Parameters:
  • rows (int) – Number of rows in grid.
  • cols (int) – Number of cols in grid.
  • spacing (float|int) – The cell width.
  • start (point) – The bottom-left coordinate of the grid.
  • style (Maze_Style) – An object specifying how the maze path is to be drawn.
Returns:

A path shape.
Return type:

dict
algoraphics.mazes.process_neighbor(coords, direc, neighbor_mat, style)¶

Call draw_cell() on neighboring cell.

Parameters:
  • coords (tuple) – The current (r, c) coordinates.
  • direc (int) – Direction of neighbor to process (0=d, 1=r, 2=u, 3=l).
  • neighbor_mat (numpy.ndarray) – A boolean array with dimensions (rows, cols, 4) indicating if neighboring cells are connected.
  • style (Maze_Style) – An object specifying how the maze path is to be drawn.
Returns:

Path list for neighboring subtree.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.mazes.rotate_cell(path, times)¶

Rotate path/s at right angles within grid cell.

Parameters:
  • path (list|tuple) – A path list or tuple of path lists.
  • times (int) – Number of 90 degree counter-clockwise turns.
algoraphics.mazes.translate_cell(path, coords)¶

Translate path/s to grid coordinate.

Treats grid cells as having width 1.

Parameters:
  • path (list|tuple) – A path list or tuple of path lists.
  • coords (tuple) – The (r, c) coordinates to move to.

paint.py¶

Create blow-paint effects along shape boundaries.

algoraphics.paint.blow_paint_area(points, spacing=20, length=40, len_dev=0.25, width=5)¶

Draw a blow-paint effect around an area.

Creates ‘fingers’ of paint projecting from each edge, as if being blown along the page perpindicular to the edge.

Parameters:
  • points (list) – The vertices of the polygonal area.
  • spacing (float) – Average distance between paint fingers.
  • length (float) – Average length of the paint fingers.
  • len_dev (float) – The standard deviation of finger lengths relative to length (so it should be less than 1).
  • width (float) – Average thickness of each finger.
algoraphics.paint.blow_paint_line(points, line_width=10, spacing=20, length=20, len_dev=0.33, width=5)¶

Draw a blow-paint effect connecting a sequence of points.

Creates ‘fingers’ of paint projecting from each edge, as if being blown along the page perpindicular to the edge (in both directions).

Parameters:
  • points (list) – The points to connect.
  • line_width (float) – The thickness of the line (excluding the fingers).
  • spacing (float) – Average distance between paint fingers.
  • length (float) – Average length of the paint fingers.
  • len_dev (float) – The standard deviation of finger lengths relative to length (so it should be less than 1).
  • width (float) – Average thickness of each finger.
algoraphics.paint.blow_paint_spot(point, length=10, len_dev=0.7, width=3)¶

Draw a paint splatter.

Creates ‘fingers’ of paint projecting from a point.

Parameters:
  • point (tuple) – The center of the splatter.
  • length (float) – Average length of the paint fingers.
  • len_dev (float) – The standard deviation of finger lengths relative to length (so it should be less than 1).
  • width (float) – Average thickness of each finger.

ripples.py¶

Create space-filling ripple effects.

algoraphics.ripples.ripple_canvas(w, h, spacing, trans_probs=None, existing_pts=None)¶

Fill the canvas with ripples.

The behavior of the ripples is determined by a first-order Markov chain in which events correspond to points along splines. The states are ‘S’, ‘R’, ‘L’, and ‘X’. At ‘S’, the ripple begins in a random direction. At ‘R’, the ripple turns right sharply until encountering a ripple or other barrier, and then follows along it. Likewise with ‘L’ turning left. At ‘X’, the ripple moves straight forward +/- up to 60 degrees. Higher state-changing transition probabilities result in more erratic ripples.

Parameters:
  • w (int) – Width of the canvas.
  • h (int) – Height of the canvas.
  • spacing (float) – Distance between ripples.
  • trans_probs (dict) – A dictionary of dictionaries containing Markov chain transition probabilities from one state (first key) to another (second key).
  • existing_pts (list) – An optional list of points that ripples will avoid.
Returns:

The ripple splines.
Return type:

list

space_filling.py¶

Fill regions by iteratively placing randomly generated objects.

algoraphics.space_filling.filament_fill(direction_delta, width, seg_length, color)¶

Generate filament fill function.

Parameters:
  • direction_delta (Param) – Parameter that will become the delta for the filament direction.
  • width (float|int) – Width of the filament.
  • seg_length (float|int) – Average side length of each segment.
  • color (Color) – Color specification for filament segments. A separate copy is used for each filament in case it involves deltas/ratios.
Returns:

A function used by fill_region().
Return type:

function
algoraphics.space_filling.fill_region(outline, object_fun, max_tries=None)¶

Fill a region by iteratively placing randomly generated objects.

Parameters:
  • outline (dict|list) – A shape or (nested) list of shapes that will become clip.
  • object_fun (function) – A function that takes bounds as input and returns one randomly generated object. Usually this is a lambda function that calls another function using arguments passed to the function that produced the lambda function. i.e., def caller_fun(args…): return lambda bounds: helper_fun(bounds, args…)
  • max_tries (int) – If not None, the number of objects to generate (including those discarded for not filling space) before giving up and returning the region as is.
Returns:

A group with clip.
Return type:

dict

svg.py¶

write SVG files.

algoraphics.svg.write_SVG(objects, w, h, file_name, optimize=True)¶

Write an SVG file for a collection of objects.

Parameters:
  • objects (dict|list) – A (nested) collection of objects. Placed onto the canvas in order after flattening.
  • w (int) – Width of canvas.
  • h (int) – Height of canvas.
  • file_name (str) – The file name to write to.
  • optimize (bool) – Whether to optimize the SVG file using svgo.
algoraphics.svg.write_filters(filters)¶

Generate an SVG representation of all filters used in graphic.

Parameters:filters (list) – A list of filters.
Returns:An SVG encoding.
Return type:str
algoraphics.svg.write_frames(fun, n, w, h, file_name)¶

Write multiple frames of randomized objects.

Frames can then be combined into an animated GIF.

Parameters:
  • fun (function) – A function called with no arguments that returns an SVG object collection.
  • n (int) – Number of frames to generate.
  • w (int) – Width of the canvas.
  • h (int) – Height of the canvas.
  • file_name (str) – A file name (without extension) to write to. File names will be [file_name]_0.svg, etc.
algoraphics.svg.write_object(obj, defs, filters)¶

Generate SVG representation of object.

Parameters:
  • obj (dict) – A shape, group, text, or image dictionary.
  • defs (list) – A list of strings used to collect SVG representations of all clip paths, filters, etc.
  • filters (list) – A collection of filter dictionaries used thus far so that duplicate filters can reference the same definition.
Returns:

An SVG encoding.
Return type:

str
algoraphics.svg.write_style(style)¶

Generate an SVG representation of an object’s style.

Parameters:style (dict) – A dictionary with attributes as keys. Underscores will be replaced with hyphens, which are not allowed in keys.
Returns:An SVG encoding which should be inserted between the quotes of style=”…”.
Return type:str

algoraphics.text.hazy_text(text, height, spread, density, min_size, max_size, fill)¶

Generate text with hazy dots effect.

Similar to splatter text but dot size is inversely proportional to square root of deviation, and points are uniformly jittered.

Parameters:
  • text (str) – The text.
  • height (float|int) – The line height.
  • spread (float|int) – Standard deviation of point jittering.
  • density (float|int) – Number of dots per pixel.
  • min_size (float|int) – The smallest dot radius.
  • max_size (float|int) – The largest dot radius.
  • fill (color) – A fill color or function.
Returns:

A list of circle shapes (in random order).
Return type:

list
algoraphics.text.splatter_text(text, height, spread, density, min_size, max_size, fill)¶

Generate text with paint splatter appearance.

Parameters:
  • text (str) – The text.
  • height (float|int) – The line height.
  • spread (float|int) – Standard deviation of point jittering.
  • density (float|int) – Number of dots per pixel.
  • min_size (float|int) – The smallest dot radius.
  • max_size (float|int) – The largest dot radius.
  • fill (color) – A fill color or function.
Returns:

A list of circle shapes (in random order).
Return type:

list
algoraphics.text.squiggle_text(text, height, spread, density)¶

Generate squiggly line text.

Parameters:
  • text (str) – The text.
  • height (float|int) – The line height.
  • spread (float|int) – Maximum deviation of point jittering.
  • density (float|int) – Number of spline points per pixel.
Returns:

A list of splines.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.text.text_points(text, height, pt_spacing, char_spacing=0.1, grouping='points')¶

Generate points that spell out text.

Text starts at (0, 0) and should be repositioned.

Parameters:
  • text (str) – The text.
  • height (float|int) – Line height.
  • pt_spacing (float|int) – Approximate distance between adjacent points.
  • char_spacing (number) – Size of the largest space on either side of each character relative to line height. This space is shrunk for certain characters depending on shape.
  • grouping (str) – ‘points’ to return list of points, ‘strokes’ to group by stroke.
Returns:

Either a list of points or a list of lists of points in which each list of points corresponds to a pen stroke (i.e. what can be drawn without lifting the pin).
Return type:

list

textures.py¶

Add textures and shadows to shapes.

algoraphics.textures.add_paper_texture(obj)¶

Recursively apply paper texture to objects.

Parameters:obj (dict|list) – A shape or (nested) list of shapes.
algoraphics.textures.add_shadows(objects, stdev=10, darkness=0.5)¶

Add shadows to objects.

Each element (nested or not) of the list is replaced with a group with shadow filter. So items that are shapes will have their own shadow, while an item that is a (nested) list of shapes will have one shadow for the composite object.

Parameters:
  • objects (list) – A list of objects (can be nested).
  • stdev (float|int) – Standard deviation of shadow gradient.
  • darkness (float|int) – A number below one for lighter shadow, above one for darker.
algoraphics.textures.billow_region(outline, colors, scale=200, gradient_mode='rgb')¶

Fill region with billowing texture.

Parameters:
  • outline (dict|list) – The object that will become the clip.
  • colors (list) – A list of Colors to cycle through.
  • scale (int) – The distance in pixels for each color cycle.
  • gradient_mode (str) – ‘rgb’ or ‘hsl’ to indicate how the gradient is interpolated.
Returns:

A group with clip.
Return type:

dict
algoraphics.textures.billowing(w, h, colors, scale, gradient_mode='rgb')¶

Generate a billowing texture.

Parameters:
  • w (int) – Width of the texture.
  • h (int) – Height of the texture.
  • colors (list) – A list of Color objects to cycle through.
  • scale (int) – Distance in pixels for each color cycle.
  • gradient_mode (str) – ‘rgb’ or ‘hsl’ to choose the appearance of the gradient.
Returns:

A PIL image object (i.e. not a dict).
Return type:

Image
algoraphics.textures.filtered(obj, fltr)¶

Apply filter to object.

Parameters:
  • obj (dict|list) – A shape or (nested) list.
  • fltr (dict) – A filter.
Returns:

A group with obj as members and filter applied to group.
Return type:

dict
algoraphics.textures.tear_paper_rect(objects, bounds)¶

Add effect of tearing a rectangle around an object.

Parameters:
  • objects (dict|list) – A shape or (nested) list of shapes.
  • bounds (tuple) – A rectangle will be torn just inside these bounds.
Returns:

A shadow-filtered group containing a clipped group containing original shapes.
Return type:

dict
algoraphics.textures.with_shadow(obj, stdev, darkness)¶

Add shadow to an object.

Like add_shadows() but returns a group with a single shadow filter.

Parameters:
  • object (dict|list) – A shape or list of objects (can be nested).
  • stdev (float|int) – Standard deviation of shadow gradient.
  • darkness (float|int) – A number below one for lighter shadow, above one for darker.
Returns:

A group with obj as members and filter applied to group.

tiling.py¶

Fill a region or the canvas with tiles or webs.

algoraphics.tiling.delaunay_edges(points)¶

Find edges of Delaunay regions for a set of points.

Parameters:points (list) – A list of points.
Returns:A list of line shapes.
Return type:list
algoraphics.tiling.delaunay_regions(points)¶

Find the Delaunay regions for a set of points.

Parameters:points (list) – A list of points.
Returns:A list of triangular polygon shapes. Items do not correspond to input points because points on the periphery do not have finite regions.
Return type:list
algoraphics.tiling.fill_ishihara_spots(outline, spacing=10, radius=None)¶

Fill a region with randomly sized spots.

The spots are reminiscent of Ishihara color blindness tests. The spots are not completely non-overlapping, but overlaps are somewhat avoided by spacing out their centers.

Parameters:
  • outline (dict|list) – A region outline shape.
  • spacing (float) – The approximate distance between the centers of neighboring spots.
  • radius (Param) – The spot radius. By default the radii range from spacing to spacing / 5 in a geometric sequence. If provided, it is recommended to supply a parameter with ratio < 1 so that spaced-out larger points are plotted first, with progressively smaller points inserted between existing ones.
Returns:

A list of circle shapes.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.tiling.fill_nested_triangles(outline, min_level, max_level, color=None, color2=None)¶

Fill region with nested triangle pattern.

Parameters:
  • outline (dict|list) – A region outline shape.
  • min_level (int) – The level of the largest triangles (0 is bounding triangle).
  • max_level (int) – The level of the smallest triangles.
  • color1 (color) – The color for half of the triangles. This can be a function.
  • color2 (color) – The color for the opposing half of the triangles. This can be a function but this half of triangles will all be one color because it is the background.
Returns:

A group with the outline as clip.
Return type:

dict
algoraphics.tiling.mitchell_points(n, n_cand, bounds)¶

Generate random but evenly-spaced points.

Parameters:
  • n (int) – Number of points to generate.
  • n_cand (int) – Number of candidate points to generate for each output point. Higher numbers result in higher regularity.
  • bounds (tuple) – A bounds tuple.
Returns:

The generated points.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.tiling.nested_triangles(tip, height, min_level, max_level)¶

Generate nested equilateral triangles.

Parameters:
  • tip (point) – The tip of the bounding triangle.
  • height (float|int) – The height of the bounding triangle (negative for upside-down triangle).
  • min_level (int) – The level of the largest triangles (0 is the bounding triangle).
  • max_level (int) – The level of the smallest triangles.
Returns:

A list of triangle polygon shapes.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.tiling.tile_canvas(w, h, tile_fun, tile_size=500, regularity=10)¶

Fill canvas with (uncolored) tiles.

Parameters:
  • w (int) – Width of the canvas.
  • h (int) – Height of the canvas.
  • tile_fun (function) – A function that accepts a list of points and returns a list of shapes.
  • tile_size (float|int) – The approximate area of each tile.
  • regularity (int) – A value of one or higher, passed to mitchell_points.
Returns:

A list of shapes.
Return type:

list
algoraphics.tiling.tile_region(outline, tile_fun, tile_size=500, regularity=10)¶

Fill region with (uncolored) tiles.

Parameters:
  • outline (dict|list) – The shape/s that will become the clip.
  • tile_fun (function) – A function that accepts list of points and returns a list of shapes.
  • tile_size (float|int) – The approximate area of each tile.
  • regularity (int) – A value of one or higher, passed to mitchell_points.
Returns:

A group with clip.
Return type:

dict

Return type:list

trees.py¶

Generate trees.

algoraphics.trees.tree(start, direction, branch_length, theta, p)¶

Generate a tree with randomly terminating branches.

Parameters:
  • start (tuple) – The starting point.
  • direction (float|int) – The starting direction (in degrees).
  • branch_length (Param) – Branch length.
  • theta (Param) – The angle (in degrees) between sibling branches.
  • p (float) – The probability that a given branch will split instead of terminating. Recommended to have a delta < 0 or ratio < 1 so that the tree is guaranteed to terminate.
Returns:

A list of line shapes.
Return type:

list

  • doodles (list) – A list of Doodle objects.
  • rotate (bool) – Whether to place the grid in a random rotated orientation.
Returns:

A clipped group.

dict
algoraphics.wrapping_paper.grid_wrapping_paper(rows, cols, spacing, start, doodles)¶

  • cols (int) – Number of columns to include.
